'''William Paul Joseph McCrossan''' (born May 20, 1942) is an [[actuary]] and former [[Canada|Canadian]] [[Member of Parliament]].

==Background==
McCrossan was born in Toronto. An [[actuary]] by profession, McCrossan has served as president of the [[Canadian Institute of Actuaries]]. He was employed by [[Canada Life Financial|Canada Life Assurance]] prior to being elected to the House of Commons.

==Politics==
He represented the [[Riding (division)|riding]] of [[York—Scarborough]] as a [[Progressive Conservative Party of Canada|Progressive Conservative]] from 1978, when he was elected in a [[by-election]] until his defeat in the [[Canadian federal election, 1980|1980 general election]]. As an MP, he introduced a private member's bill, Bill C-255, the ''Public Pensions Reporting Act'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://laws.justice.gc.ca/eng/P-31.4/page-1.html |title=Public Pensions Reporting Act (1985, c. 13 (2nd Supp.)) |work=Canada Department of Justice - Statutes by Title|accessdate=2009-11-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Brown|first=M. David R. |date=October 1999|title=The Public Role of Actuaries in Private Pensions in Canada - 7. The Public Pensions Reporting Act|journal=North American Actuarial Journal|publisher=Society of Actuaries|volume=3|issue=4|pages=28|url=http://www.soa.org/library/journals/north-american-actuarial-journal/1999/october/naaj9910_4.pdf|accessdate=2009-11-15|doi=10.1080/10920277.1999.10595856}}</ref> which passed unanimously. He also supported the passage of the ''Non-smokers' Rights Act'', which was introduced by a [[New Democratic Party (Canada)|New Democratic Party]] member of parliament, [[Lynn McDonald]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=McCrossan|first=Paul |date=Winter 1990–1991|title=Parliament and the Private Member |journal=Canadian Parliamentary Review|volume=13|issue=4|url=http://www2.parl.gc.ca/Sites/LOP/Infoparl/english/issue.asp?param=135&art=876|accessdate=2009-11-15}}</ref>

He was re-elected in the [[Canadian federal election, 1984|1984 election]], but lost to [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal]] [[Jim Karygiannis]] in the redistributed riding of [[Scarborough—Agincourt]] in the [[Canadian federal election, 1988|1988 election]].

He attempted to return to [[politics]] in the riding of [[Scarborough East]] in the [[Canadian federal election, 2000|2000 federal election]] but was defeated.

==Later life==
From 1995 to 1996, he was president of the [[International Actuarial Association]]. In 2001, he was named to the Standards Advisory Council of the [[International Accounting Standards Committee]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-10349839_ITM|title=IASC Names Advisory Council.(International Accounting Standards Committee)|last=Randall|first=Robert F. |work=Strategic Finance |date=August 1, 2001 |accessdate=2009-11-15 | date=2001-08-01}}</ref> He was a consulting actuary and partner at Eckler Partners Ltd., now known as Eckler Ltd. He served on the advisory committee for Sir [[Derek Morris (academic)|Derek Morris]]'s review of the actuarial profession in the [[United Kingdom]], known as the ''Morris Review''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-13545428_ITM|title=Review of actuarial profession.  |date=October 1, 2004 |work=Morris Review via M2 Presswire|accessdate=2009-11-15}}</ref>

In 2010, McCrossan was named to the [[New Brunswick]] [[Task Force]] on Protecting Pensions.<ref>[http://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/news/news_release.2010.12.1849.html Pension task force members named], Government of New Brunswick, Justice and Consumer Affairs, 7 December 2010.</ref>
